But praise to those in high offices, who did make things go."
"Sad joint, dead on a weekend night. Told we'd get in free, still almost empty. Go-go dancers, but that's it. One beer, then bounced in under 30 minutes."

"Stayed at this joint for a conference. Big place, nice pools, lounge areas. But our room reeked. Musty, smoky. Made me unhappy. My girls and I had separate rooms. First night, one of 'em woke up with six, seven bites. Uncomfortable, itchy the whole trip. Second night, I got bit too. Went to sleep fine, woke up with two bites on my ankles. Never had the doors open, slept with the blankets covered. Bed bug problem, I reckon. Last night, got bit twice more. Now I'm home, happy to be here. Itchin' like mad, feelin' dirty. Give 'em two stars for the facilities, but gettin' bit ain't acceptable."

"Costco ain't what it used to be. This 'business center' in Vegas, it's a joke. No booze, no grub, just a bunch of overpriced snacks and drinks for vending machines. Place was dead too, only a few workers and they didn't know squat. Asked about coupons, waited in line, and they don't even take 'em. Back in L.A., that's where the real Costco's at. That's where I'll be doin' my shoppin' next time I'm in Vegas."

"Anthony, a true New Yorker, served us at the Italian place today. He was top-notch, like a fine wine. Helpful, attentive, and a real pro. He even gave us a taste of the soup before we ordered. Bravo, Anthony! 

Now, the grub...mixed bag, like life itself. Tilapia, a hit with my compadres. But, kitchen, what's with the uneven portions? You gotta step up your game. 

I went for the minestrone, but it was more tepid than a summer evening in the Hamptons. Sadness. Meatball sandwich? Lukewarm and too much salt. Not fresh, like a day-old rose. 

But, the lemon cookies, oh man! They saved the day, like a Hemingway novel. Not too sweet, just right. Enough lemon zest to make you pucker up, but not too much. Shareable, like a good joke. 

And, the sign on the door, a new era begins. Smoke-free, like a spring breeze. Feb 1, mark your calendars."

"Alas, how changed this place doth seem,
Its former charm now lost in dream.
Where once warmth and character did abide,
Now naught but sterility doth reside.

Oh, for some cushions on those chairs,
And fabrics soft to ease our cares.
The light and ceilings high, they do impart
A sense of space, a feeling of art.

But that bare wall, so plain and cold,
Doth bring to mind a certain hold.
Nay, 'tis the Birdcage apartment, I swear,
Where Nathan Lane did once appear.

Yet, for small weddings, this place doth suit,
With dance floor central, all quite neat.
But, alack, the food doth leave much to seek,
Rice dry, beans tasteless, salsa weak.

Guacamole with cottage cheese, oh fie!
Chili colorado, just thick and naught else, I see.
Service slow, unhelpful, and prices high,
Yet, for the cheese crisp, nine dollars, I would buy."

"Sunset Station, better than expected. Gus had dinner plans, so I was on my own. Decided on Fatburger after walking around a bit. Young lady was friendly, took my order of a burger and onion rings, believed the sign about their famous onion rings. Also got a shake. Why am I a fat old man? Order came quickly, back to the room I went. Burger was a mushy mess, hated it. Onion rings were bland. Shake was...ok. Someone suggested Fatburger recently, remembered this experience, shuddered, never again."

"Underwhelming experience with too much repetition."

Food was good, not great. Small portions. Stand in line, sit down, wait for grub. Like McDonald's. Thai Dynamite was tame, sesame chicken mediocre.

Saw a mess while we dined. Spilled salt or sugar by the door. Server almost fell, four staff walked by, cleaned up 5-10 minutes later. Accident waiting to happen.

Won't be back."

"Methinks I came to this place, with four stars on Yelp,
My love and I, in search of Mexican cuisine, did help.
I ordered the green chili plate, my love, the burrito,
We shared the menudo, with high hopes, did we commit.

But lo, the food, so bland, lacked flavor,
We thought Filerberto's, a better savor, would show.
The service, swift, the server, kind,
Yet, alas, the grub, our taste, did not bind.

So, farewell, dear restaurant, we shall not return,
For elsewhere, our hunger, better dishes may learn."

"Hark! My friend, I didst say, 'Let us yelp this place ere we enter.' Alas, how mistaken I was to forego that notion. 

Upon our entrance, the establishment appeared tidy and inviting. Our server, though solitary, attended to us with reasonable haste. 

I ordered a fish burrito, which arrived some fifteen minutes later. Alas, 'twas a sorry sight: undercooked rice, a paltry amount of vegetables, and fried breaded shoe leather masquerading as fish. Fie upon it! I have had better fare at Del-Taco across the way. 

My comrade chose chicken sizzling fajitas, which arrived in haste, smelling sweet and sizzling fiercely. Yet, alack! The flavor was wanting, and the sides--undercooked rice and ancient salad--left much to be desired. The guacamole and sour cream, however, were fresh and pleasant. 

Note, good sir or madam, that the salsa was quite tasty, full of zest and a gentle heat. Should you desire chips, salsa, and ale, then by all means, partake. But, prithee, avoid this place, lest thou desirest a culinary disappointment."
"Tomahawk steak, special, $98. Glazed sea bass, $39. Asparagus, $14. Hand-cut fries, $12. Not exactly bland, a bit too salty though. Blood pressure'll spike. Ambiance, chic. Bathroom, unique."

"Clothes good, staff bad. Always messed up when I come here. Today, five items at counter, four at home. Kid manager took over 'cause others didn't know what a check was. He struggled for ten minutes, ignored me. Finally rang it up. Grrrr, hate going back."
"Prices, fair. But 45 minutes for a wash and vac? Too long. Not sure if I'll return."
"Fair grub. Liked the idea, liked my first time. Only thing that hit the spot was the Red Jade bird."

"Slow, real slow. Like molasses in January. Place was dead, but still, they couldn't get their act together. No using the app, no sir. Gotta give 'em your phone and let 'em punch in the numbers themselves. What a pain."

"Came here with the folks before Zumanity. No wait time, but shoulda waited. 

Drinks: Sangio, normally good, but didn't finish the glass. Mom's limoncello cocktail was alright. 

Food: Soup and salad special - cucumbers, tomatoes, onions, red vinaigrette, feta. Salad was rough, tomatoes were cold, didn't eat it. Mom's rare veal ($30+) was over-marinated, still had a vinegar taste. Didn't like it. 

Service: Server didn't check in till we were done. Supervisor came over, offered to replace the salad and veal. Didn't have time, didn't charge us for those two."

"Food was average, service was poor. Four of us dined, three meals were decent, but my son's Philly cheesesteak was a soggy disaster. We considered sending it back, but the waitress didn't return to check on us. When she finally came by, she went through the motions, clearly uninterested in her job. My son asked for water, which she forgot. I won't be returning on our next Vegas trip."
"Philly cheese steaks, slow service, 15-20 bucks.  Flavorless sandwiches, fries too.  TVs blasting loud, sensitive ears beware.  Limited seating."

"Avenue Q, brilliant. Traveling cast, keep in mind. Gammage Auditorium, not impressed. Outside, cool. Inside, outdated. Bathrooms, gross. Handicap inaccessible, half the floors. No elevator, rudely told. Walk slowly, cane, few stairs, nearly killed me. Didn't go to restrooms, no way in hell. Almost burst into tears. Had to rinse and repeat, get down. Multiple flights of stairs, people pushing, rude ushers. Classist and ableist, both."

"Hour upon hour didst I wait, my stomach doth grumble and churn.  A feast fit for a king, or so I didst hope, yet naught but woe didst it bring.  Pancakes of banana, a dish most foul, chewy and dense, like a loaf of bread gone bad.  And the skillet, devoid of taste, a mere shadow of its former self, a culinary disgrace.  Alas, poor cook, what hast thou done?"

"Mid Town Pub, a joint I've hit up often, but now it's time to move on. Last time I ordered the chicken cordon bleu, but what I got was some chicken with a ton of jalapenos. I flagged the mistake, they fixed it quick, but the replacement had ham and was still infused with jalapeno flavor. Didn't touch it, but they charged me anyways. Figured I'd give 'em another shot on my latest visit, but the sandwich was inedible. Way too salty and peppery. One bite and I was done. This kitchen needs some serious help. Peace out, MTP."

"Stayed here with the missus while on business. Had a suite looking out onto the courtyard. Real nice, but the delivery trucks and tour buses made some noise. Two busloads of Japanese tourists, bright and early. Then there was the happy hour, 5:30 to 7:30, free drinks in the breakfast room. Place was packed with old folks, sipping their cocktails and beer. My wife and I shot some pool, good times. Like a nursing home, but livelier."

"Methinks 'tis a noble notion, this eatery of old,
With decor and ambiance, both neat and bold.
Clean, comfy, and inviting, a place to behold,
Yet service, alack, did leave somewhat to be desired, I do confess.

A family of gluten-free folk, we sought refuge here,
Excited by the menu, with options most dear.
Veggie Antipasto, flatbread trio, chicken Caesar,
Two pizzas, all GF, our taste buds did stir and stir.

Alas, the crust and flatbread, hard and flavorless were,
My homemade pizza crust, or Whole Foods', far better, by far.
The sauce, too sweet, the salad, drowned in dressing,
Antipasto, flatbread, dips, all lacking in zest and relish.

A pity, indeed, for we had hoped to find
A haven of healthy fare, our taste buds to entwine.
Mayhap, in time, they shall improve, and we shall see,
A change for the better, and give it another chance, mayhap, anon."

"Hark, a vegetarian I be, and thus didst seek
This place, of which much praise didst speak.
But lo, my hopes were dashed, for they didst serve
Actual meat, in a vegan restaurant, oh so dire!

My tea, unsweetened and mixed with mango,
Was delicious, I must confess.
The side salad, with my pannini, was quite nice,
But the pannini itself, alas, didst not impress.

A to-furky pannini, I couldst have made at home,
And saved myself the trouble, and the woe.
The red velvet, though, didst please my taste,
But 150 calories and 5 grams of fat, oh what a waste!

Alas, the service was slow, and we didst wait,
For our food, and for the bill, a sorry fate.
Two other tables, there were, and yet,
We didst not feel welcome, nor didst we get

The attention we deserved, or the speed we sought,
And thus, I fear, I shall not return, norought.
A sad conclusion, to a night so bright,
But thus, my friends, doth end my tale, a sorrowful plight."
"Terrible service from our waitress. Busboy was attentive though. Give him her job. Food was meh, overpriced. You're paying for the ambiance, I reckon."

"Food was spot-on. Ambiance, top-notch. Service? Abysmal. 

Hostess, apathetic. Like she'd been there too long, didn't care. Told us table being set up, silverware taking its sweet time, like it was flown in from China or somethin'. Waited 30 minutes for that nonsense. 

Server, no better. Took 20 minutes to bring menus, another 20 for drink orders and food. Then, another 20 for half the party's drinks. Had to hunt him down for round two drinks, promised but delayed, of course. 

Waiter said Vintner's got Strip-quality grub off the Strip. Newsflash: Strip-quality food comes with Strip-quality service. 

Shame, really. Food was good, ambiance, great. Service? A joke. Wouldn't recommend it."

"Alack, my heart did sink, my spirits did flag,
When first I heard of Buffalo Exchange, a place
Where designer goods, at prices low, did flow.
But lo, my hopes were dashed, my dreams did break,
For within its walls, a sight did make me quake.
The same as Plato's Closet, a place I do detest,
With clothes that none would want, and service, a jest.
A multitude of folk, did wait with bated breath,
To hear their fate, and learn if their clothes had worth.
But nay, not one, did leave with a smile so bright,
For all their wares, were naught but tatters and spite.
I gazed around, and saw not a single thing,
That would make my heart sing, or my spirit take wing.
And thus, I knew, that I would ne'er return,
To this place, where hope doth dwindle, and despair doth burn."

We strolled down the strip, a couple pals and I, and passed by this joint blasting music. We wouldn't have stopped, but our buddy wanted a couple brews at the bar 'cause they were two for the price of one. This dude outside tried to hustle us for $15 each to get in, but we declined and kept walking. Our pal was still getting his drinks, so we waited. The guy came up to us again and offered us a deal for $10 each, but we still said no. Finally, after some persistence, he let us in for free. We hung out for a bit, maybe an hour, and the music was good, drinks were reasonably priced, but the women weren't impressive, even with a few drinks in me, and the dudes there seemed like douchey frat boys who got kicked out of their frat. We took off, and I doubt I'd go back.
"Three lousy chicken fingers, drowned in a heap of greasy fries. How's that for a rip-off? Nine bucks, and not worth a penny more."
"Inspection and oil change, one guy working alone. Communication, like a cave man. Not going back."

"Methinks 'tis folly to dine here for Mexican fare,
For naught but woe doth lie within this place,
No pride in prep or presentation doth show,
But blandness doth abound, alack the day!

The service, verily, doth shine so bright,
Yet cannot make amends for foul repast,
From chips to finale, all doth falter,
And noise, aplenty, doth assail mine ears,

With screaming bairns and misbehaved sprites,
That doth detract from any culinary joys,
So, gentle friends, I pray thee, seek elsewhere,
For better fare, and quieter, too, God willing."

"A decade past, I didst visit this place,
And savored prime rib, crab, and seafood with grace.
But now, alas! The menu doth bear a change,
With Chinese, Mexican, and fruits in range.
No real potato dishes, save mashed, didst I spy,
And sushi, once a delight, now doth fail to fly.
But still, the prime rib doth please, crab doth abound,
And calamari, a delicacy, doth astound.
Pre-made salads, alack! Doth leave much to be desired,
And my dear husband, a man of meat and fires,
Doth find but little sustenance to assuage his hunger.
A price, I pray, that doth match the selection's lack,
And more sushi, that doth taste of sweetness and delight,
And hot crab, in abundance, doth make all right."

"Loved the old salty senorita. Great burritos, fundido cheese dip, steak salad, margaritas - the works. Never thought a new spot would change things. Ordered an appetizer and margarita, but no frozen machine yet. Understood, new location. Ordered chicken burrito and fajita. Appetizer never came, main course was subpar. Rice was hard, beans were too. Chicken was alright. Asked for hot sauce on the side, they put it in. Needed a drink after that meal, but never got it. Service was mediocre. Bring back my old salty senorita!"
"Staff, nice. Price, too high. Pastrami sandwich, no bueno. Restaurant, potential. Me, no return."

"Chips and fries, good. Menus, scattered. One by door, one behind counter. Should be easy, but no. First time, we order. Hotdog, where? Girl says, behind us. Course it is. No ice, I ask. Refresh, she says. Wait, she says. Cashiers, grumpy."

"Rawhide ain't for everyone. Kids might dig it, but for two grown adults, there ain't much to do. We shelled out five bucks for parking and spent half an hour walkin' around the "town". Took a few pictures, but that's about it. Not worth your time, in my book. Unless you're real big on western stuff, then maybe you'll find it interestin'. But I wouldn't put it high on your to-do list."

"Hark, what news is this? A yogurt place most fair,
And near at hand, a convenience beyond compare.
The price, a steal, a mere.35 per ounce,
A bargain, indeed, for those who dance and prance.

But lo, my friends, a problem doth arise,
For when we sought to partake of their prize,
The shop, alas, was dark, and void of life,
Despite the claim, a voicemail did convey.

A message left, a plea, a cry, a wail,
For those who ran the shop, to heed our tale.
How can a business thrive, with such deceit?
A mystery, a riddle, a puzzle, a feat."

"Skip this joint. Waited 45 minutes for a table, and they ain't clearin' 'em fast enough. Food's mediocre at best. Got a beef short rib, but the meat's too tough and gristly. Can't even cut it with a knife. Stay away from this place. Buffet's got some decent grub, but the wait for a clean table makes it not worth it. Don't waste your time."
"Service was slow, real slow. Got there at five, place was dead, still took forever to order. Fish fry cost me 17 bucks. Jesus."

"Wife and I hit this joint for some sandwiches. Thought about Quizno's, but saw this place and gave it a shot. Ordered Chicken Gyro, Chicken Kabob, and Baba Ghanouj to go. Mind wandered to "Kitchen Nightmares" while waiting. When the grub was ready, we grabbed it and took off. Chicken Gyro had big slices, not bad, but could've been thinner. Pita bread was soaked from the tomato and onions. Kabob was a letdown, thick and dry. Expected chunks, not strips. Baba Ghanouj was gross. Tasteless mixture drenched in olive oil. One bite was enough. Best I had was at "Sabuddy" Israeli spot, now closed. Owner went back to New York. Pita bread was solid, though. Next time, I'll stick to in-house orders."

"Went here based on price and reputation. Walk-in only, no appointments. Waited 90 minutes. Didn't specify gender, good thing since I don't care. Told him to focus on neck, shoulder blades, and sciatica. He asked how long for each area and what trigger points for sciatica. Poor time management, didn't know anatomy or terminology, and fussed with sheets too much. Took five tries to get the sheet right. Afterwards, no water or recommendations. Proceed with caution."
"Tuesday, 1:00 pm. No line. Quick service. Chicken wings, ABC burger, strawberry sundae. Huge portions, mediocre taste. Overpriced. Sweet potato fries, enjoyable."

"In-room dining, a bust. Called ahead, asked about wings, price and quantity. They said six for $16 during the day, twelve at night. Ordered at 11 PM, got six. Called again, they said twelve. Put me on hold, came back, said menu changed. Didn't know their own menu. Poor service. Bought two orders, twelve wings for $41. Wouldn't have ordered if they were upfront. Not full, not satisfied. Order in-room dining often, this was bad. Delano, otherwise okay. Less crowded, nice hotel. Quote of the day by the elevators, my favorite."

"Tourist trap, indeed! Fair location, grand building, and pleasant layout, yet prices inflated, like a bloated bladder. Margaritas, good, but dear, two to three coins too much, for each style. Chips and salsa, five coins? Tsk, tsk! Fresh, they should be, for a tortilla factory, nay? Tortillas, passable, not great, alas! Carne fuego, a disappointment, small bits of steak, lost in a sweet and spicy sauce, like a maiden, weeping. Veggies, mediocre, and the sweet potato-stuffed chile, strange, like a distant cousin, twice removed. Alas, avoid this place, unless your Aunt Hattie, naive to Mexican fare, doth visit from the land of Ohio."

"$185 for a round of golf and the fairways are still covered in grass clippings? Come on, guys. I'm not asking for perfection, but for that kind of cash, I expect a little better maintenance. The greens were slow and the whole course was in pretty rough shape. I get that everyone's going through overseed, but charging top dollar for a subpar experience is a bit rich. Give me We-ko-pa or Troon North any day."

"Service here? So-so at best. Kids behind the counter? Unattentive. Had to shout to get their attention. Location's only saving grace is its spot at the bottom of Las Sendas hill. Otherwise, wouldn't return. Store Manager/Owner, this is your chance to make it right. Fair reviewer here, and this place is the weakest in the Mesa Valley.

Rosatis? Good, but nothing beats Chicago pizza. Water quality out west ain't great. This Rosatis does a decent job though. Kid who took our order was chill, brought it out fast and hot. Sausage? Awesome. Visit this place every time we see Dad/Mom, since they live nearby. Tip? Order extra cheese. Worth it. Grease drips everywhere, especially from the pepperoni."

"Cheap rooms, $35 a night. Fat Tuesdays' giant Everclear drinks, can't recall much after that. Comfy beds, clean. Hairdresser Elvis. 

Resort fee, $5 a night, not included in quote. Two polite staff members. One laughed at friend requesting towels. Far from strip, near downtown Vegas, preferred that. 

Topless pool, full of pro-wrestler types and large women in thongs. If comfortable with your body, go for it. Prefer nicer hotel, better staff, and save on cab fare. 

P.S. Why bring kids to Vegas????"

"Tired of eating at joints claiming to serve up authentic flavors from across the globe, but delivering nothing more than bland imitations. Not an expert on Greek grub, but I know what's good and what's not. Can spot the difference between fresh and stale. Vegas, baby, you gotta bring your A-game or fold. No room for laziness when it comes to quality. Don't wanna be the next casualty of the economic downturn."
"Vegas, baby. Glitzy, once. Now, divey. Not easy to navigate. Drive, an option. Airport, meh."

I went in to check the prices and see what they offered. The moment I walked in, a wave of stench hit me. I know having many dogs in a small space won't make it smell like roses, but I'd hope they clean the place occasionally. I asked about a service listed on their flyer and website and was told they don't offer it. Why list it, then? I also didn't like that from the front office, I couldn't see into the area where they kept the dogs, though I could hear them going wild. As I left, I noticed through broken blinds, there were many dogs in a small space with no one around. Side note: the couches in the photos on Yelp looked dangerous, too broken to be safe for dogs. I won't be back or using their home service. It would have been perfect, since I live just a mile away.

"This joint's alright. Food's nothing special, just your typical tropical crap. Atmosphere's like a fancier TGI Fridays, but instead of crappy decor, it's more upscale tropical. Not worth going back to unless someone else is footing the bill."
"Place ain't what it used to be. Broth's gone thin, portions shrunk, service still slow. Time to find a new joint for my pho fix."

"O, woe is me! This cupcake, a bitter taste doth bring. Worse than the ones from yonder grocery store, I do declare. And pricey, too! In Vegas, of all places, where excess doth reign. Yet, hark! The shakes, they doth please my palate still."

"Hark, what wondrous sight doth meet mine eyes! A pastrami sandwich, piled high with delight. The little lady, with her skilled hand, doth layer on the meat, as if 'twere a treasure to behold. My mouth doth water at the mere thought, as I await my turn to partake. Alas, when finally 'tis placed before me, I find myself deceived. The flavor, so bold and peppery, doth fail to make its mark. I add some salt, a dash of mustard, yet still, the taste doth linger, leaving me perplexed. Methinks 'twas but a strange occurrence, a freakish slab, forsooth. I shall return, in hope of finding truth in this delicatessen's renown."
"Food was too oily. Chicken skin peeling off, strange. Pricey for mediocre Asian-Fusion. Been to better, cheaper places."

"Ho there! Alack, my dear, 'tis true, this feast doth leave me unimpressed, I pray thee, let it not be so. 

A youth, with waters and teas, didst bring us drink, but knew not what he served, alack! And, lo, no straws were proffered, a peeve most vexing, that doth make me shun the cup, in haste. 

The egg rolls, full of scent, didst taste of perfumes, and chicken chow mien, but fair, at five and nine pence, for lunch, betwixt the days of Monday and Friday, inclusive. 

And, mark thou well, no ask was made, if dessert we wouldst have, or no."

"Tivoli Village, empty as a ghost town. Two women chatting, didn't even notice me walk in. Then, they warmly greeted the folks behind me. Rest of the staff, watched me like a hawk, like I was some kinda thief. Either I was invisible or they thought I was a kid trying to steal their crap. Place sells cheap accessories at inflated prices. Not worth it. Might find something decent on clearance, but never pay full price. It's junk."

"Alas, I wish I had perused the Yelp reviews ere booking my stay,
For the bathroom, small it was, and the door, it did not open wide.
The power plugs, loose they were, in the bathroom, a sight most vile,
And throughout the chamber, none could be found, a true trial.

We stayed for two nights, and service, we did not receive,
Though I did call the front desk, to inform them of our leave.
Twice, I did notify, but naught, it seemed, did they conceive,
And so, our room, unkempt, did remain, a true grief.

I sent my garments, to the dry cleaner, with haste,
But come the morrow, they were not ready, alack!
Two hours late, we were, and still, they did not arrive,
A further forty-five minutes, did pass, ere we did depart.

And when I called, to inquire, the lady at the desk,
Was as unpleasant, as one could be, a true curse.
I shall not return, to this hotel, again,
For service, poor, and accommodations, did not please."

"Chicken teriyaki bowl, that's the ticket. Forget the rest. I had the tempura and teriyaki combo for lunch, but it wasn't worth the price. A carrot and zucchini, that's what they called tempura. And a shrimp tail, but it wasn't even as big as a pencil. Two CA rolls, but no ginger or wasabi. What's the point? Not worth $10.82. They need better lunch deals."

"A gathering of kin we did convene,
And with great hope, my spirit did gleam.
But alas, the victuals, merely passable they were,
The service, woeful, left much to deplore.

A reservation, we had made with care,
Yet still, the staff did seem unaware.
We waited long, our orders to procure,
Until at last, my husband did ensure.

Wine and water, thrice I did request,
As did others of our merry quest.
But nay, the servers did neglect,
Our thirst, they did not soon inspect.

So to the bar, my spouse did stride,
And served our party, he did provide.
Alack, the evening, it did not bode well,
Our feast, it did not fare so swell."

"Food Lion, southwest corner of Sandy Porter and Tryon. Prices higher than Harris-Teeter, Bi-Lo, Wal-Mart, Super Target. Full grocery selection, including frozen, dairy, produce, beer, wine, meats. Not cheap. MVP shopper loyalty card available, saves you money."

"Dinner was a bust. Waitress forgot some grub and didn't bring my order right. Then she disappeared after bringing the check and refilling our drinks. I had to get up and grab a refill myself. No one cared. New waitress showed up after an hour and offered more drinks, leaving our dirty cups on the table. We weren't asked if we wanted anything else over two hours. And the women's restroom? Two stalls were out of TP. What a mess."

"Tropicana, huh? Yeah, I stopped by a few times. It's alright, I guess. Just your typical resort snack bar stuff, but a bit pricey. Gelato's not bad, but seven bucks for a couple scoops? Nah, man. Bellagio's got better deals. Fro-yo's not bad though. Forty-nine cents an ounce, and some weird flavors. Coconut, peanut butter, cake batter. Never got the fro-yo thing myself. Just makes me want real ice cream."

"O, woe is me! This airport doth vex my soul.
I thought O'Hare was bad, but this place doth take the cake.
The lines, they stretch on forever, a never-ending plight.
The TSA folk, dimwitted as can be, doth make my blood boil.
And, oh, the slots! They do add to the din and chaos,
Airports already busy, now my head doth throb with pain.
McCarran, thou art a trial, a true test of my patience."

"Hark! All this talk of Tao Beach, a place of wonder, they say. But lo, when I arrived, 'twas naught but a disappointment. A pool, small and shallow, fit for children, not a haven for men. And yet, for women, free of charge, a boon, no doubt. But for the men, a fee to pay, and an open bar, with limitations, alack. Verily, I say, for those who seek a finer experience, look elsewhere, fair sirs. Wet Republic, a better choice, with larger pools, and greater luxury, methinks."

"Hark! What light through yonder cafe doth break? A meal most vile, with naught to make it great. Two eggs, some sausage, toast, and home fries, all drenched in grease, did make my stomach churn. The coffee, too, did lack in taste, and left me in a state of woe. The waitresses, old and worn, did seem to know their craft, but alas, their service did not make up for the fare. In brief, a poor excuse for sustenance, The Smithfield Cafe doth prove."

"Hark, good sir or madam, listen well,
For I shall speak of prices most foul.
At this establishment, they do charge
A pretty penny, for a meal most bland.

The dishes, they do range from beef to pork,
From soup to rice, and noodles, of course.
But alas, there's nary a signature dish,
To make one's taste buds sing with delight.

Their glasses, white and orange, are quite fair,
And the decor, it doth please mine eyes.
The service, it was adequate, I dare say,
And the food, it was cooked with care, in truth.

But lo, the noodles, handmade they were,
Were the highlight of our feast, by far.
And the shrimp, seasoned with salt and pepper,
Did tickle mine taste buds, in sooth, most tender.

Now heed my words, dear reader, take heed,
For the portions, they be small, indeed.
So order wisely, lest thou leave unsatisfied,
And heed not the prices, lest thou be misled."

"Cut outta there when I realized I could do better than a hundred bucks a night. Place was stuck at the end of the strip, casino was mediocre, rooms were straight outta '97, and the whole joint smelled like that damp towel you forget in the hamper for two weeks. Two stars, tops. Girl came up to our group, tried to pick us up, then stumbled off with a dude's shoe print on her leg. Classy."

"I read the other reviews and wonder if we dined at the same joint. I get two spicy tuna rolls with brown rice. Flavorless, like Elmer's paste. Maybe I picked wrong. Seemed like a good idea at the time."

"Good value for the price. Clean, comfy, modern digs in a sweet spot. Free wifi, decent gym. Outdoor fire pit's a nice touch. Menu's got some great options. But, heads up, the nearby clubs can get pretty loud, especially on weekends. If you're looking for a peaceful night's sleep, might want to reconsider."

"I'm from San Diego, love all things Mexican, and fish tacos are essential. But this joint? More trendy than good. Got my tacos, looked decent, but the fish was breaded at the restaurant. Why bother? The fish was alright, but I got pieces. Typically, if you cut it right, no pieces. The batter was meh, and I've had better fish sticks from Gorton's. Flavorless. Seemed like they just decorated, but I felt like I got leftovers. Looking elsewhere for fish tacos. If you're in San Diego, try Rubio's. Fast food, but they know what to serve and what not to. Cabo's didn't feel that way. Could've gotten the same dinner for half the price with more flavor."
"Food's good. Had bibimbap. Service? Shit. Terrible. Can't believe how bad. Forced 18% tip. No way I'm going back."

"Went on the 28th, December 2014. All good, 'cept the steak. Not the quality I'd hoped for. Been to plenty of steakhouses, know my way 'round a good cut. This joint? Overpriced. Oysters, though? Not bad."

"I'm revisiting my review of this joint for two reasons. First, it's been a while - 2009 to be exact. Second, my recent visit wasn't like the first. I'll keep it brief for you non-readers. The burger was flavorless. I get the unlimited toppings thing, but even A-1 sauce, chipotle, and banana peppers couldn't mask the dry, ground beef taste. Cheeburger, step up your game! Chili's has its own flavor! I was let down, but I'm over it now since I won't be coming back."

"Place was decent. Never been here before, surprisingly. Hit the buffet, $8.50 with soda, give or take. Reminded me of Shakey's, but not quite up to par. Like Chuck E. Cheese, but a step above. Salad bar was basic, but I liked the peperoni. Pasta was spaghetti and elbow macaroni, two sauce options. Ragu, but a bit better. Chicken and potato wedges were the same, tasted the same too. First round, no pizza. Second round, pizza was mediocre, pre-cooked sausage, lots of grease. If I had kids, might come back after sports games, otherwise, no plans to return."

"Arrived in Madison, tired from travel. Hungry, needed a hot meal. Looked for veggie-friendly delivery. Found Nepalese place near hotel. Prices seemed steep, but I figured portions would be big. Ordered soup, got a small cup for over $10. Didn't order anything else. Still hungry. Bummed out."

"Echo Canyon, once my heart's delight,
Hath now been marred by man's blight.
The parking, oh how it doth fail,
A barricade, a ranger, and naught but wail.

Five cars, at most, can wait,
And not block the road, a poor fate.
The trail, once stairs, now steep and rough,
Compressed gravel, a slippery enough.

No dogs, alas, nor friends out of breath,
For this trail, a challenge, a test of death.
But past the parking, the trail doth remain,
The old Echo Canyon, a memory, a pain."

"Chinese takeout joint. Hard to find good one. This place, Hoho Cherry House. Used to be Hoho China Bistro, but it moved. Lunch specials, decent value. Food, average. General Tso's, okay. Like Panda Express, but family-owned. Expected more. Not bad, but nothing special."

Alas, fair friends, I bring tidings of woe,
For at the chain, my hopes were laid low.
I sought the pumpkin spice, a flavor so bright,
But alas, 'twas absent from my sight.
My friend, who hath tasted, doth concur,
That pumpkin's essence was not there, anon.
The brew I sipped, had naught amiss,
But lacking pumpkin, 'twas a disappointment, I must confess.
A seasonal special, with pumpkin's absence, doth fail,
And thus, my friends, my review doth falter and wail.

"O, woeful day! My journey through yon drive-thru doth crawl at snail's pace, and my brew, alas, doth suffer grave injustice. Alack, the baristas, though fair and pleasant of demeanor, cannot make amends for a latte, poorly fashioned, that doth cost a pretty penny. Nay, I wouldst venture forth, out of my way, to seek the haven of Starbucks, where Trop and Fort Apache do meet."

"Food, top-notch. Summer evening, bar sparse with a handful of regulars, couple of 'em drunk. Lady yappin' away like she owned the joint. Seemed like they all thought the world was their playground. Me? I'll stick to the birds, they make more sense. V's should cut off the sauce for those two, that's my take."

"O, how I detest this update to write,
For 'twas a place I held in high delight.
Apple Spice, thy name doth now connote
A series of mistakes, a woeful plight.

Three times, they've failed to get it right,
Ten lunches, a simple task, yet still they fight.
Bread bowls, small containers of soup,
And bread, a meager serving, doth not suffice.

The southwestern salad, sans cheese, I did request,
Yet chicken, it did contain, a thing most vexing.
A sandwich, not a wrap, did Heather receive,
And cookies, juice, both absent, did she perceive.

Replaced were the mistaken items, 'tis true,
But the delay, an hour, did my hunger accuse.
Expensive, the Southwestern, not worth the fee,
And mistakes, thrice, doth Apple Spice decree.

Alas, I must bid thee adieu,
For thy mistakes, they do my patience undo."

"Yalla opened near my house, and I was stoked. We needed a solid Mediterranean spot, and it being owned by Khoury's, my favorite, was a bonus.  Ordered a few things - roasted chicken sandwich, Fatoush salad with chicken, beef kabobs. Rice was top-notch, crispy noodles, light oil. Hummus, too. Fatoush, tasty. Hubby, no complaints on the sandwich. But, some issues. Billed wrong, cashier apologetic but still overcharged me. Pita bread, not great either. Back though? Yeah."

"Update: Went back, waited ten minutes behind another customer at the counter without a word from the cashier. Woman couldn't get her order together, and we were ignored. Left. Awful service. Cashier should've acknowledged us, offered to start our order while the customer ran out to her car. Nothing. Awful. Went to Osaka across the street."

"Went with a Chinese friend. She ordered in Chinese, shouted at the waiter when she didn't like the look of it. Food was exceptional. Best Chinese in Central Illinois, but that's not saying much. Couldn't recreate the experience though. Asked her to write me a note in Chinese for the same dishes. Showed it to the waiter when I went alone, but it wasn't the same. Expect it was the shouting. Now that she's gone, it'll never be that good again. Without her, it's just a mediocre joint."

"Pros: Fast, friendly service. Comfortable beds. Nice tub, though small.

Cons: Unfriendly staff at check-in. No outlets by the bed. No freezer, only a fridge. No vending machines. Complicated room controls. Bathroom sinks are a mess.

Reminds me of The Hotel, but I prefer The Hotel to Aria."

"Been to one other Brazilian steakhouse before, in Dallas. That one was damn good. Not the case with Braza's. Food didn't taste fresh, like it'd been sitting under a warmer too long. Meats were just alright. Flank steak was good, chicken was good, sirloin was okay but bland, pork was good, lamb was okay, alligator (yep, alligator) was decent. First time tryin' it. \nAtmosphere was a letdown. Website made it look like a fancy 4 or 5-star place, but it was more like a Golden Corral inside. Not exactly a place to impress the missus. Plus, it smelled like an Indian restaurant, since it's split in half - Indian on one side, Braza's on the other. Service was good though. Friendly staff, wanted us to have a good time. Pricing was around $40-45 per person. Felt like I could do better elsewhere for that price."
"Manager's not too keen on helping out at Petco. They never got what I needed in stock. Closer to home than PetsMart, but after three strikes, I'm switching to the competition."

"Great expectations, based on reviews. Seated quick, but waiter acted like we were inconveniencing him. Ordered scampi, slightly overcooked, burnt tails, good pasta and sauce. Friend ordered cod, extremely overcooked, asked for new piece. Waiter whined to coworkers that we sent food back. Won't be going back, will discourage friends."

Alas, my dearest wife and I didst venture forth to this establishment, forsooth, upon the Isle of Style's renovation. Methought I had espied this place afore, and thus, didst decide to partake in their culinary delights. Verily, I do confess, I am glad that I didst, for now I know to ne'er return anon.

I do not reckon the exterior's visage doth matter, for 'tis the victuals and servitude that doth hold my interest. My spouse and I didst request the luncheon bill of fare, but alack, 'twas not proffered. The attendance was adequate, yet my displeasure lay primarily with the viands.

Chinese cuisine, by my troth, shouldst burst with bold flavors and crisp, fresh vegetables, in sooth, a feast for mine eyes. Alas, this hot pot of pork and tofu, a humble, uninspired dish, with naught but lettuce, a poor excuse for a garnish, doth fail my expectations.

Moreover, the pan-fried noodles with shrimp, a dish I held in high regard, proved itself to be insipid, lacking the verve and zest I had anticipated. Methinks the cooks herein, have lost their ardor for their craft, a sorrowful state, indeed.

In conclusion, a disappointing experience, with naught to commend the service, and, alack, the food, a sorry lot, indeed. I fear, I shall ne'er return to this place, nor wouldst I recommend it to mine enemies, let alone, my friends.

"Food's good, but servers don't know squat. Ask 'em about the menu, they just shrug and stammer. 'Kenyan food? Like American food.' 'Menudo?' Blank stare. Nice atmosphere, though. Shame about the staff."

"A sign didst proclaim, 'All You Can Eat Sushi, for $19.95.'
'Twas a claim that didst stir within me, great skepticism and doubt.
For who couldst provide such a feast, and at such a low cost?
I didst fear, the quality of the food wouldst be quite lost.

And thus, my fears were confirmed, when I didst partake,
Of the sushi, which didst taste, of naught but rice and fake.
The fish, it didst seem, was scarce, and the rolls, they were fat,
With rice, that didst overpower, the flavor of the dish, alas.

But lo, my friend, he didst order, a bowl of miso soup,
Which came, in a large portion, and thus, didst make me drool.
For four dollars and fifty cents, a price most fair,
It was a steal, and worth it, beyond compare.

I didst skip the sushi, for I didst suspect,
'Twould be a poor excuse, for a meal, and not worth the inspect.
So I didst choose, the Ah Sin Fried Rice, instead,
But found it lacking, in flavor, and thus, it didst not please.

I also didst try, the Har Gow, shrimp dumplings,
Which were surprisingly good, but still, not worth the plummet.
For though they were tasty, they were not the best,
I have had better, and thus, I must confess.

And lastly, they didst charge, for hot tea, eight dollars,
For a pot that didst serve, five people, and thus, it didst border.
On the expensive side, it didst seem, to me,
But still, I didst pay, and thus, it didst set me free."

"La Condesa, I've had enough. We've tried to justify the poor service, but no more. It's too sluggish, unresponsive, and they just don't care. Not worth it. This time, the food was also subpar. We sent back the watery horchata and they replaced it after we finished eating. They drizzled a pretty crema all over my torta. How am I supposed to eat it? In the past, we overlooked the filthy tables and noise because the cochinita pibil was divine. But that's not enough to make up for the service. Had enough."

"Prices on meat and fish are damn good here. That's why I come. Produce is mediocre, but I buy milk often 'cause it's always on sale. Can't pass up the deals on meat and fish, though. Buy one, get one or two, you know? 

Service, though...total shit. Cashiers are slow and rude. Don't even acknowledge you most times. Checkout takes forever. 

Still, I'll keep an eye on their ads and come back for the sales. Just glad this ain't my only grocery option."

"Don's my cup of tea, too Yuppie. Atmosphere's too sanitized, servers got no personality. Food's fair, but not worth the price. Where's the red sauce? I'm Italian, I need red. Ordered from the Small Bits Menu, thought it'd be a light lunch. It was small, alright. Needed more bread just to feel like I ate somethin'. If you wanna be full, get the dinner menu. Most folks are more sophisticated than me, they can figure out the fancy California stuff."
"Breakfast with the boys was a letdown. Waffles and pancakes, but no flavor. Lemon pancakes, really? More like plain old pancakes. Presentation was alright, but that's not enough. Won't be back."

"Avoid this joint like the plague, folks. Smells like cheap teen perfume up in here. Overpriced goods and dim-witted staff. But hey, not all bad - decent men's sweatpants to be found. Just don't pay full price, and wash 'em good when you get home. They'll reek like their cologne otherwise."

"Hark, what woe is this! A $50 ribeye, so fine and fair, yet cut with a dull steak knife, that instrument of sorrow. Alas, my mind doth conjure up but one memory of this place, and 'tis a vision of sawing through my steak, a task most vexing and tiresome. Fie upon this wretched blade, that doth mar the joy of savoring such a delicate and delectable morsel!"
"Tamales, that's what I came for. But, damn, they were a letdown. Lukewarm, flavorless, and poorly prepared. Service? Forget about it. El Sombrero, that's where I should've gone."

"Methinks each time I take up club and ball,
This course doth stir within me wrath and gall.
Today 'twas slowness that did vex mine eyes,
And made me curse the heavens with bitter sighs.
We played but thirteen holes in three long hours,
And waited five or more minutes at each tower.
I pray thee, do not come to this fair place,
If thou desirest to play a swift round with grace.
Nor shalt thou use the vending machine so bright,
That doth reside upon the fourth hole's green sight.
Forsooth, I didst waste half my day in waiting,
And thus, we didst leave, with hearts still fretting.
Yet, shall I say, the greens were in good fettle,
And thus, two stars I give, not one, I reckon.
For I, a golf snob, do take offense,
When for thirty pieces of silver, I do not make sense."

"Food? Forgettable. Service, now that's a different story. Our server, a gem. Two steaks, medium rare, one cooked medium-well, the other, blue rare. Raw, practically. Noise and bustle, but our server, top-notch. Time, we had little, but she tried her best to fix the mess."

"Hark, good sir or madam, pray tell me this:
Why doth it seem, no matter the hour of day,
That waiting time doth stretch and never pass?
Methinks 'tis due to lack of staff, they say.

A plague upon this woeful wait, I pray!
How vexing it doth be, to stand and stay,
When hasty feet do eagerly await
Their turn, to dine within this hall of play.

Oh, wouldst thou, management, take heed
And hire more folk, to speed the deed?
Forsooth, 'twould ease the burden, and make merry
The hearts of those who doth await their turn so dreary."

"Wahoo's ain't what it used to be. Fish is dry, green sauce is nasty. Bartender's got a bad attitude, turns down the TV volume during a fight, ignores me when I ask for it back on. She's too busy chattin' up some dude to do her job. Place is a dump, avoid it."

"Hark! This market, a Las Vegas best, doth serve
Breakfast on weekends, a feast most fair.
Akin to Whole Foods, yet prices more just,
We ordered at the counter, then didst sit
In the piano room, where our meal didst arrive.
Eggs over easy, with bacon, toast, and spuds,
The ingredients were fine, but the price too steep,
And the cooking, alack! Left much to seek.
The toast not crispy, the bacon limp and weak,
The potatoes tired, the egg whites watery.
Alas! A disappointment, this market doth be."

"Walked into this joint, felt like I'd been there before. Standard buffet, food stations from around the world. No wait, which should've been a red flag. 

Overpriced, mediocre grub, terrible service. Waitress dumped our OJ and disappeared. 

Realized I had been there before, back when it was at the Aladdin. They just moved it to Planet Hollywood. 

No line for a reason - it was crap. Can't believe I blew my Sunday brunch here."
"Tacos, once again, failed to impress. Mushy centers, questionable fryer time, and subpar guacamole. Pricey too, six-fifty with tax. Not worth it, even after a few drinks."

"O, fair Aureole! How lovely art thou to behold,
Thy victuals, most divine! Yet, alas, thy service doth falter,
Like a ship without a rudder, lost at sea.
Reservations made at nine and thirty, we didst arrive,
And waited, waited, waited, for our turn to dine.
The waiter, he didst disappear, leaving us to ponder,
Their tablet, broken, with nary a drop of wine to savor.
He returned, some twenty minutes passed, with a scowl upon his face,
As if we were to blame for the device's disgrace.
Then, four times, he warned us, 'We'll be closing soon,'
As if we were not aware, the hour grew late, the moon full.
Food, oh food, how magnanimous! So very, very good!
But, alas, the pressure, to hasten and depart, didst leave a foul mood.
No more, dear Aureole, shall we return, forsooth!"

"Terrible's, just down the road from my place. Stop in for a cold one on my way home. Car wash? Once. Overpriced and underwhelming. Gas? Nah, too expensive. Convenience store? Decent selection, fair prices. Beer cave? Best in town, hands down. Parking lot? A pain, but worth it. Employees? Minimum wage, minimum effort. Still, it's my go-to spot."

"Methinks 'tis strange, my friends, that e'er I had
Good fortune here, in days of yore,
But now, alas! Our feast doth suffer woe,
For service dire, doth make us sore.

First, waiter dear, didst forget our place,
And left us, in a sorry state,
Then came a maid, with scowl upon her face,
And answered our queries, with disdain and hate.

Fare, though passable, didst lack its former grace,
In days of old, when we didst dine,
With joy and mirth, in this self-same space,
But now, alack! 'Tis naught but woe and sorrow doth entwine."

"Werner Enterprises truckers come here. I'm one of 'em. It's got the essentials we need. I've seen worse digs. If you're looking for luxury, keep moving. Two-star joint at best. Plenty of grub nearby though."

"This joint's got nothin special goin on. Foods alright, I guess, but the service is slower than a snail on a hot summer day. And dont even get me started on the seating arrangement. Its like they gotta cram as many tables in here as possible, so youre practically eatin off the same plate as the folks next to you. Not exactly the most pleasant dinnin experience, if ya know what I mean."

"Fare was passable, yet naught excelled. A twelvemonth past, my feet didst stray not hither, and now, alas! I know full well the cause. For juice of orange, two hundred fifty pence they didst demand, and freely poured, no more they wouldst proffer. Verily, victuals were middling, yet superior dishes elsewhere beckon."

"Craved wings, drove for 'em. Good, but rubs too salty. Had Louisiana, Parmesan Garlic. Ate Louisiana, not Parmesan. Parmesan cheese smelled like spoiled dishrag. Stunk up my ride home. Tossed it straight in the trash. Won't be back. Staff got no sense of smell?"

"Alack, my lads, what folly led us here,
To this, the nearest buffet, so dear?
Forsooth, the price we paid, a sum most great,
Could've bought us passes, for a longer treat.

But still, we sat, and waited for our feast,
And when our server came, our thirst he did quest.
We made our choices, from the limited fare,
And found some joy, in grilled meats so rare.

Short rib tacos, sushi, and beef Wellington too,
Were the bright spots, in a meal most woe.
But alas, the rest, did leave us cold,
Mini churros, hard, and ice cream, old.

Our server, helpful, but our drinks, he did confound,
So full, yet dissatisfied, we rose from ground.
Away, my lads, let's not return again,
For better fare, our coin we shall maintain."

"Told to check out this Vegas buffet, I regret I did. Two types of folks: buffet lovers and those who don't. I'm the latter. Reminds me of college mess halls. Still, we went for Saturday brunch. Variety seemed decent - Asian, Italian, seafood, pizza, breakfast. Omelet was the highlight. Rest was meh, limited by no meat. Desserts looked nice, but didn't impress. Fiance was adventurous, thought food was mediocre. We'd prefer a better restaurant, less food."

"Rave reviews, huh? Crowded, you say? What the hell, I thought. Pros: cheap. Cons: subpar food, undercooked pork, fake cheese enchiladas, stale marshmallows. And don't even get me started on the freakishly obese people. Woman, that was your fifth cotton candy."

"In person, the staff doth seem friendly and helpful,
But o'er the phone, they doth not even bother,
They've called me to come early, only to switch doctors on me,
The office, alas, is not very clean,
I had hoped ne'er to return, but they would not respond,
To my prescription refill requests, and so I had to go,
In person, to fix the situation, they did tell me,
That every three months, I must come in to be seen,
But when I questioned this, they did fold and give me my script,
It seems they wish to force thee to have much done,
To line their pockets with thy insurance, perchance,
I am back to hoping ne'er to need to go again."

"Monday, I hit up this takeaway joint for the first time. Had the Kung Po chicken. Won't be doing that again. Breaded chicken, sticky sauce - more like sweet and sour. Not the authentic Chinese I was looking for. And overpriced. Stick to the places on Leith Walk."

"Pancho Villa's been kickin' around for a bit, gets enough business to keep the lights on, but I ain't exactly sure why. Had better chili at other joints, and Illegal Jack's too. Enchiladas and fajitas? Meh, they were lackin' somethin'. Friend told me they make a killer margarita, but if I gotta be drunk to enjoy the grub, ain't worth the restaurant prices."

"A pox upon the pizza, priced so steep,
At Dominos, where the deals do creep.
A medium pie, with two toppings, they say,
Yet costly, it doth make one pause and pray.
A low rating, for price doth not align,
With quality, or value, we doth decline."

"Pool's clean, architecture's neat. But why concrete the deckin' in this heat? Slippery, hot. Someone slipped, hit their head, ambulance came. Lifeguards outnumber guests three to one. When someone gets hurt, all guards blow whistles, corral everyone outta the pool, no exceptions. Not even for kids or towels. Ridiculous. Won't be back."

"This joint's way overpriced for what you get. Sure, the waiter was polite and all, but for the money we spent? Nah. Food was decent, not great. But hey, when you're shelling out over a hundred bucks a pop, you expect more. Like, exceptional grub and top-notch service. Instead, we got lukewarm dishes and tiny portions. And don't even get me started on the unisex bathrooms. People were lining up just to use 'em. All in all, this place ain't worth the cash. It's just an average spot with some fancy presentation."

"Service of registration was naught but woe,
A maiden fair, with mood didst change,
Didst greet all others with a smile and grace,
But when my turn came, didst she show disdain?
I know not why, but thus didst she behave,
And left me feeling most unpleasant, indeed."

"Mac n cheese, fish, side salads, clam chowder. Salads came first, then soup, then Mac. We joked about the appetizer thing. Our entrees arrived, lots of plates. Waiter cracked a joke. I gave him a look. Three servers, food runners, refills, grabbing salt and pepper, no leadership. Good deco, good food. Giving them another shot. Service needs work. POS system should track food timing. Miscommunication between servers and cooks, management problem."

"Alack, how times have changed! This place, once fair and bright,
Hath now descended downward, nigh to night.
Our waiter, slow to greet, didst take his time,
Twenty-seven minutes passed, ere he didst incline
To take our order, and with speed, we prayed,
Lest he disappear, and leave us dismayed.
The menu, once diverse, hath now been pared,
Leaving few options, and those, not well prepared.
I had the bbq chicken flatbread, alas,
The chicken, dark and lean, with fat and gristle, was.
A burger, perchance, might still be worth the fray,
But this dish, sadly, didst not pass the day.
Management, it seems, doth suffer here,
And staff, in turn, doth falter, and appear
To lack the zeal, that once didst make this place
A worthy start, in this fair city's race.
We shall not return, but hope, in time,
They mend their ways, and regain former prime."
"I requested delivery. No issues, arrived in 30-40 minutes. Just ordered rolls. Salmon was flavorless, California rolls were mediocre. Paid the delivery woman, she left without a word. Meh."
"Pho? Don't know what that is. Smells off, tastes worse. Asked for extra veggies, got less than usual. Seat's torn up, feels like sitting on razor blades. Not worth it."

"Mexican joint, Phoenix. Unremarkable. Subpar grub. Two enchiladas, one chicken, one beef. Meh. Dark brown sauce, questionable. Beef sauce, forgettable. Tacos, no bueno. Dead Friday at 12:30pm. Punch machines idle, kiddo scootering, skeleton crew. Doubtful about their future."

"Been here twice. Service stinks. Slow as hell. Don't know if they're short-staffed or what, but it's painful. Food's mediocre. Bar food, nothing special. Could be great, but they gotta step up their game. Competition's fierce next door."

"Hark, what news is this? A place that doth sing,
Where cooks do croon, and service doth bring,
A sense of family, and warmth doth flow,
Like a great feast, where all do glow.

The decor, alas, doth lack some sheen,
But still, this place doth hold some scene,
Fresh pico de gallo, spicy and bright,
Doth dance upon the tongue with delight.

And when the cooks do sing, 'tis a treat,
For then thou know'st the food will be sweet,
Flour tortillas, simple, yet divine,
With only six ingredients, so fine.

But alas, the guacamole, oh how sad,
Doth contain a thickener, making it bad,
And rice, too small, doth dry out fast,
A shame, for it doth not last.

But fear not, for the cheese crisp doth please,
With fresh green chili strips, a tasty tease,
So let us hope, this place doth find,
A way to improve, and thus be defined."

"Tis priced too steep, a double shot of brew,
At JPH, the cost doth make me pause and sigh.
In fair Handsome Roasters, I didst partake,
A pull of espresso, by an owner's hand, didst make.
And lo, 'twas cheaper than at JPH, I swear,
In LA, where prices do ascend so high.

In Barista, Portland, a barista of renown,
Didst pull a double, and the cost didst astound.
Cheaper than JPH, 'twas a wondrous sight,
A marvel, indeed, in this city of delight.

Coava, Stumptown, The Refinery, I didst visit,
Pretentious, perchance, yet cheaper, I didst witness.
A place of luxury, for those who can afford,
Yet, I, a humble soul, do enjoy, now and then, to partake.

Rent, expensive, mayhap, or trust funds, abound,
Or loans, taken, to feed a coffee habit profound.
Let us be reasonable, my friends, I pray,
For LADRO, served here, doth bring a smile, each day."

"Blue Wasabi. Avoid it. Inflated reviews, average food. Good service, sure. Decent drinks, too. But, for the price, you get mediocre sushi. Not worth it. Sushi on Shea and Kyoto, now those are good eats. Cheaper, too. Don't waste your cash on the scene at Blue Wasabi. You'll regret it."

"Friday eve, about nine o'clock, I chanced upon this place,
And found it lacking in staff, with naught but two servers to grace
A large establishment, and no hostess in sight.
My server, though, was quite good, his service most delightful and bright.

The food, alas, did not match his excellence, I do confess.
Lemon sole, a side salad, these were my choices, nothing more,
Yet with tax and tip, the sum totalled twenty dollars, I do declare.
The salad, fresh and crisp, was pleasant to the taste,
But the lemon caper sauce, oh how it failed to impress!
The sole, sauted, they claimed, yet fried and tough it was,
A shame, for sole is tender, and needs but little cooking, alas.

Disappointment filled my heart, and I would not recommend this dish,
For Mimi's bread, though good, cannot make up for such a failure, I do wish.
Expensive, too, this meal, and not worth the cost, I must confess.
Go elsewhere, friends, and save your coins, for here you'll find but woe and distress."

"This joint gets rave reviews, but I just don't see it. It's grimy, run down, and the service is painfully slow. And let's not forget the food - it's nothing more than greasy, bland slop. 

People say it's a great spot for affordable, delicious Mexican cuisine, but that's just not true. The salsa is store-bought and the guacamole lacks any real flavor. And don't even get me started on the tortilla chips - they're covered in shredded cheese that's not even melted. 

I tried a taco salad and couldn't even stomach finishing it. If you're in the market for subpar, Americanized Mexican food, then this might be your place. Otherwise, steer clear."

"Manager says he's gonna treat himself to Blueberry Hill. I near fall outta my chair. Seen my review on Flamingo? Terrible! But he insists, says it's 10,000 times better on Green Valley Parkway. I shrug, go back to work. Today, I need somethin' to get the creative juices flowin', so I figure, why not? Get to Blueberry Hill, order the same as before - Mexican-style chilaquiles and a Diet Pepsi. Same plate of mediocrity. Don't see how folks rave 'bout these places. Service a little faster, but still not sold. Stickin' with Denny's for comfort food."

"Alas, the sauces they did proffer, were naught but a paltry few. And the ribs, oh how they did disappoint, small and lean, like those of a babe. Other meats they did present, brisket, chicken, pork and sausage, but alas, they did lack a certain je ne sais quoi. The waitress did claim, that the sausage was made on site, but verily, it did taste most generic, like unto a packaged fare from Costco's Hillshire Farms. The steak fries, the only side I did partake, didst bear a faint resemblance to those with skin, yet still, they didst taste most mediocre. In the Northwest Phoenix realm, there doth exist far better BBQ, methinks."

"Fremont Street dive, near Golden Nugget. Seen better days. 

Go for the deep fried Twinkies, 99 cents. Not good for me, but can't resist. Could use a cleaner deep fry station and friendlier service. Rude comment about tips, so I'll leave 10%. 

Slot machines don't work, staff not happy. Would be better without gambling. Good for slushy drinks and deep fried Twinkies, but avoid gambling."
"Coffee's decent, but service is lacking. Been here plenty, various times of day. Attempted small talk with baristas, got brief replies. Coffee and grub? Standard Starbucks fare."

"Ate at the seafood buffet tonight. Not worth the price. Steamed crab legs were alright. Crab legs in sweet chile sauce were better. Cold crab legs by the seafood were a bit salty. Lobster tails were small and rubbery. Everything tastes better drowned in garlic butter. 

Best part was the desserts. Green tea cheesecake was nice and light. Creme brulee was perfect. Bread pudding with vanilla spice sauce was great. Red velvet cupcakes were dry and terrible. 

Buffet is overrated. Go elsewhere. Not kid-friendly. Seating is tight. One star for food and options. Another for excellent service. Rest didn't live up to the hype."

"Underwhelmed. Got there around four, only one table occupied. Exterior looked promising, but inside felt like a tattoo artist's bedroom. Took a while for someone to come out and seat us, not a great start. Salsa bar had variety, but was set up poorly. Containers too small, had to use plastic spoons. No metal utensils or plates provided, table was a mess before we ordered. Tacos arrived, both plates had cracks. Smoked marlin tasted like canned tuna, veggies were okay. Corn tortillas flimsy, like store-bought. Service was meh, questions met with finger-pointing and blank stares. All in all, should've gone to Chipotle."
"Sunday nights, we'd hit this joint, me and the crew. Good times, cheap drinks, decent grub. Lately though, things ain't been the same. Prices up, quality down. Shame, really."
"Food joint's a real gimmick, if you ask me. Rent-an-express, that's what they call it. But hey, the grub's just alright, nothing special."

"Place was nothing special. I wasn't too hungry, still feeling the effects of a wild night before. Got the breakfast buffet for $15, pretty standard for Vegas. Pizza was a highlight, but everything else was just eggs, bacon, sausage, hash browns. Made it 3/4 through a plate before I felt sick. Service was good though, waitress gave me two big glasses of OJ. If you're staying at Planet Hollywood, it's not a bad option. But I'd go for Le Village Buffet in Paris instead."

"A cockroach emerged from yonder sprout dish,
And with its presence, did my appetite dismiss.
I slew the beast, and with some hesitation, stayed,
Their apologies were many, and my meal they repaid.
My to-go dinner, too, they gave without a fray,
But now, alas, I fear I must seek fare elsewhere,
For though 'twas once my favorite pho diner,
I shall now journey forth to Chinatown, fairer."

"Strippers. Funny as hell, trying to be sexy. But forget it if we ain't interested. Guy named Chili. Ugly bastard. Kept offering deals for a dance. None of us wanted. Some other dancers were cool, though. Met a dude from San Jose. Pretty funny. But seriously, no seats in the main room for the girl dancers? What the hell? We kept getting invited to join bachelor parties, but we didn't want to sit with them. Saw some guy getting a hand job from an ugly stripper. Hilarious."

"O, how my heart doth sing with joy and cheer,
For Pasqual's salsa, mild, medium, or hot, doth bring me cheer!
In days of yore, they didst call themselves a "salsaria,"
And with each bite, I do confess, I feel like dancing with glee!
But alas, my friends, my joy doth turn to woe,
For with a large plate of nachos, they doth serve but a tiny bit of salsa, no!
Last time, it happened, and we didst order extra,
But lo, the cup they brought, was still but a small quantity, oh so vexing!
The chicken, beef, and tacos, three stars they doth deserve,
But 'tis the salsa, my friends, that doth make it all worthwhile, I do declare!
Give me more, I pray thee, for my taste buds doth crave,
More of that delicious salsa, that doth make my heart sing and dance with glee!"

"Went out tonight with a family member, ordered the $20 dinner for two. Guacamole appetizer, their tortilla chips and guacamole with corn, no jalapenos, not spicy, according to the waitress. First bite, whoa, 5-alarm fire in my mouth, full of jalapenos and other spicy things. Sirloin, mine was well done, burnt on one side. Came with loaded mashed potatoes, great, and broccoli, foul and rancid. Service, always poor, don't know why I went back. Tonight, my last visit."
"Terrible service. Took forever to sit us down, bring our grub, and quench our thirst. Then they had the nerve to take their sweet time giving us the bill. We ain't never coming back."

"Alas, my friends, how sad it is to say,
This pizza joint did not meet the play.
Their pies, they were not of New York style,
But rather, a poor imitation, vile.

A half meatball, half pepperoni pie,
We ordered, with hope in our eyes.
But what arrived, oh how it did disappoint,
Thick crust, sauce like tomato paste, no delight.

And "meatball" as a topping, what a shame,
Ground beef spread o'er the cheese, no fame.
Sliced meatballs, that's what we desire,
Not this mockery, a burning fire.

We sought a NY style pizza place,
But alas, this joint did not embrace,
The flavors, the charm, the taste so fine,
Of the Big Apple, they did not entwine.

So we'll stick to our regular haunts,
Where pizza is served, with skill and chance.
For Streets of NY, a name so bold,
Must deliver, or be told."

"Ran through the drive-thru, first mistake. Girl at the window, clueless about the menu. Finally got my order, pulled ahead, waited. Anticipation building. Smelled onion rings on the way home, couldn't figure it out till I got there. Bag of ice cream, greasy and flavored the ice cream. No good. Salvageable ice cream, too sweet. Had to stop, fearing a diabetic coma. Quickly downed water. Meh, never again."

"Food's hit or miss here. I stick to piccatta, but the one time I tried the veal, it was tough as shoe leather. Prices are steep too. Atmosphere's the only saving grace. Staff's gotta step it up, from their attitude to their knowledge. I went to the bar and ordered a mojito. Bartender said she couldn't make it, but the manager, Mike, said they had fresh mint. I got my drink, but it made me wonder if the bartender was telling the truth or just didn't want to make it. Last June, I set up a birthday party for my husband. Made a reservation a week in advance, but the waiter and busser were MIA. Had to beg for refills. Only had one good waiter in three years, and that's because I complained to the manager and he comp'd our meal."

"Hark! What customer service doth this place provide?
Two stood there, idle, as I entered the door.
One eyed me keenly, yet didst not utter a word.
The other, a lady, didst bid me good morrow,
But swiftly departed, leaving me quite unheard.

A slice of pizza, a salad, and drink didst I seek,
Their 'number two' special, priced at six crowns.
Alas! The sauce on the pizza was overly sweet,
And the dough, it didst sag like a rain-soaked gown.
The salad, a simple mix of greens and veg,
Didst please my taste buds, but naught else didst beguile.

Thus, I didst leave, with a heavy heart and full belly,
Praying that next time, their service may be more jolly."

"A decent place, indeed, with TVs and outdoor seating,
And a roll of paper towels at every table, neatly arranged.
I am a fan of pizza and beer, 'tis true,
But alas, the beer is draft, and not meant for takeout, anew.
They have wine, as well, for those who prefer,
Their appetizers seem fair, but I didst not partake,
For I had the pizza, with vegetables upon it,
Which was but mediocre, I do confess.
Nothing too special here, I do declare,
Perhaps 'tis the location that doth make it fair."

"San Gabriel Valley born and raised, my dim sum standards run high. This joint? Subpar. Microwaved fare, flavorless and stale. Har Gow and Shau Mai, mushy and falling apart. Rice cake dessert, a disappointment. Overcooked, no flavor. For Vegas dim sum, it'll do. Won't be back."

"Apartment complex went up in flames. Had to hole up here temporary-like. Brought my kid, me, and the two cats. Asked for a handicap room on account of my bum knee. Neighborhood ain't the best, but the train noise don't bother me none. Liked the safety bars in the bathroom though. Made me feel secure, ya know? If I had to do it again, I'd still pick this Scottsdale spot."

"Place looks good inside and out. Not packed on a Friday night, so we sat on the heated patio. Started off well, good bread and fresh salads. Went downhill from there. Spanakopita starter was decent, three big pieces, but too much cream cheese. Missed the light phyllo crust. Regular gyro and chicken gyro were nothing special. Fries and rice were unimpressive. Service was good, but I won't be back."
"Tucked away in Scottsdale Quarters, upstairs from Tanzy and iPic. Don't let that deter you, keep lookin'."

"Methinks 'twas not the rub that vex'd me, fair,
But lack of folk to tend to my needs there.
The masseuse, she who kneads my sore muscles,
Doth also serve as receptionist, it seems,
And manager, and janitor, by the looks.
Each time a new guest enters, she doth leave,
To arrange their massage, and thus, my hour
Did stretch to ninety minutes, full of woe.
We chanced upon this place, near yon sushi feast,
But alas, I shall not return, forsooth."

"PB&J before 11 am? Forget about it, kid. Employees said it's against the rules, no matter how much you beg. They wouldn't even give me Tobasco for my egg sandwich. Just some weak homemade chili sauce instead. What's the point of having rules if you can't enforce 'em? Shame on 'em."

"Place had good reviews, decent happy hour prices. But it didn't do it for me. Decor was lacking, booths were uncomfortable. Service was alright. Ordered gyoza, it was okay, not crunchy though. Volcano roll was a mistake, they brought us a thunder roll instead. Rainbow roll was subpar, shrimp was chewy, avocado was off. Tea and miso soup were good. Not impressed overall, won't be back."

"Food's good, that's why I gave it a two. Been here before, always been satisfied. But this time, service was crap. Started off normal, greeted at the door, seated quick. Busy place, but not too bad. Got our drinks fast, French press was top-notch. Then, we waited. Five minutes, ten, fifteen. Others got seated and ordered, but no one bothered with us. Waitress was too busy chatting with the staff. Finally got up and left. Disappointing, especially for Postinos. Won't be back to the central location."

"Cirque du Soleil fan here. Seen O twice, Ovo, Mystere, Quidam, Zarkana, and Dralion. Zumanity caught my eye 'cause I was hitting Vegas for the first time since turning 21, and the idea of Cirque's "sensual side" fit the city's vibe. But, it didn't quite live up. Stunts weren't as impressive, and the music and dance didn't stand out. Still, if you're looking for a good time, Zumanity's got some funny "clown" hosts who'll keep you entertained, especially with crowd interaction. It's a different experience than other Cirque shows - way more intimate. Small theater, performers greet you at the door. Front-row seats mean you'll get some interaction, so keep that in mind when booking."

"Liked the bar tops, nice lighting. Fries were good. BF's bro got fish sandwich, wilted salad. Fish and chips, garlic fries good, fish not so much. Batter didn't hold up. Boyfriend had bangers, bean and mash. Tasted like breakfast sausage. Not impressed. Doubt I'll be back to this Firkin place."

"Fair sirs, the victuals were most delectable,
But alas, their cost did cause much vexation.
For three of us, the sum before gratuity
Did reach a hundred and five pieces of silver.
And though the service was quite satisfactory,
I fear the price did not merit such expense.
A plague upon these prices, say I!"

"A pox upon this eatery, I say!
Their dishes, full of fat and gristle lay.
I ordered steak, a New York cut, they claim,
But 'twas a disappointment, full of blemish and shame.
The veal, too, was naught but a disgrace,
With sauce that resembled more a gravy's embrace.
And martini, oh how it did fall short,
Sweet, yet lacking in true flavor and sport.
The service, fair, but not enough to sway,
For there are better choices, come what may."

"Perch'd upon a stool, I sipp'd a glass of vintage red,
And plac'd an order for a meal to be convey'd.
A bartender, with mien somewhat displeas'd,
Didst pour for me a draught of wine, the price whereof didst seem steep.
I ask'd for half spinach, half romain, a mix'd bed,
For my Cesar salad, and thus didst make my wish known.
The pizza, with toppings of pear and Gorgonzola, didst arrive,
But cold it was, and not so tasty, alack!
I fear I shall not return to this place again."

"Stayed at the Hilton, across the street from the Riviera. Ended up gambling there every day. Bartenders at the poker bar were friendly, but some dealers were rude. James and Bruce were great. Lost big time to Tang, no smile, no nothing. Why bother with 3-card poker? Wouldn't play there if I was with the boys instead of my family."
"$13 for two milkshakes? No way. Not in Gilbert. They weren't half bad, but no milkshake's worth that much. What a ripoff."

"Four of us hit this joint after an Overture gig. Grub was decent, but the service? Shitshow. Server cleared plates with food still on 'em. But the real kicker was our waiter. This one broad, eight months preggo, orders a virgin mojito. Waiter gives her the hairy eyeball and says, "So, you want it with vodka, huh?" She's like, "No, dipshit, without." Finally gets it through his skull. Then the bill comes and we get charged eleven bucks for this non-alcoholic drink. We're like, "What the hell?" Ask him about it, he says there ain't no button for virgin drinks and it's ten bucks for the mint and labor. We're like, "Bullshit." Ask for a manager, wait ten minutes, nobody shows. So we pay and bounce, pissed off."

"Parked, validated tickets ourselves. Left, told parking was three bucks, validation only good for three hours. What the hell? Got hit on by some dude with star-shaped implants outside the john. Weirdo. Gonna hit up College Night at Canyon Club, but they wanted ten bucks cover from underage folks. Rip-off. Just left."

"Hark! A tale of woe doth unfold,
Of empty tables, and service cold.
Three hostesses, fair and bright,
Didst banter amongst themselves, all night.
Their wit, sharp as a rapier's point,
Didst leave me standing, without a joint.
I waited, patient as a saint,
For two whole minutes, before they didst relent.
A glass of Pinot, I didst request,
But 'twas a sorry sight, I must confess.
'Twas opened long ago, I couldst tell,
And the bartender, he didst not well.
He said, "No, 'twas just opened now,"
But his words, they didst not ring true, somehow.
The Happy Hour, a paltry thing,
A dollar off, a meager offering.
The portions, generous, I will admit,
But the food, alas, was not a hit.
'Twas mediocre, save for the croissants,
Warm and delicious, but scarce, alack!
In Scottsdale, there be better places,
Where thy hard-earned coins, thou mayst dispense.
Spend not thy money here, my friend,
For thou shalt find a better end."

"Tee Pee Mexican Food, round two. Historical joint, no doubt. Weekend before Christmas, lunchtime, not too busy. Friendly service, salsa on point. Chips, small and crushed. Green corn tamale, cold. Rice and beans, meh. Hubby's carne asada burrito, better. Salsa and drinks, worth it. That's it."

"Skip Thursdays, kid. They only open the rooftop, and you're stuck in the patio's center. Fifteen feet from the rail, you're far from the action. Disappointing, especially for Vegas. I've seen better clubs in Austin, even on Thursdays. XS on a Friday night? Ten times better. Don't bother with Pure unless it's Saturday, and you're getting in free."

"Went to this joint a couple years back with the fam during a Vegas trip and loved it. Ordered all-you-can eat and my old man even got sick from overeatin'! We were eager to come back this time around.

Ordered some alligator tail as an appetizer and it was tasty. But the all-you-can-eat platters we usually get were only good towards the end. Seemed like they were usin' old oil to fry the fish and shrimp at first...yuck! Don't even wanna think about how old it was. But hey, at least they changed the oil to fresh oil at the end, so that was good.

The salad bar was pretty lackluster too. Coulda used some more maintenance, ya know? Maybe put the same items on both sides to make it easier to navigate without spillin' stuff everywhere. Did like how they kept the plates chilled though.

Service was good, our waitress did her job. Shame we lost our cravin' for this place. Just ain't the same no more."

"Staying at the W, I only ate here. Hot waitresses, sure, but that's Montreal for you. Nothing special. 

They try too hard with fancy French dishes, but the flavors don't quite work. Not impressed. 

Breakfast is alright, I guess. That's all."

"Alas, when we didst arrive at McCarren, and didst proceed to obtain the rental carriage, I didst initially think, "Hark! I have made the proper choice, for lo, there be but five or six souls ahead of me in line, while nary a single soul doth occupy the other rental carriages nearby." But alas, 'twas not the case. Why, thou mightest ask? Forsooth, upon the morrow, I didst require a carriage once more, and didst choose Budget, for their price didst rival Dollar's, and their conveyances didst appear more pleasant. Meanwhile, at Dollar, there didst but two servants attend to the throng, and verily, I didst never tarry in a line of five or six persons for such an interminable duration. 'Twas a woeful, vexing delay, which didst tempt me to cancel my reservation and seek a new one at another rental agency. Fie upon thee, Dollar!"

"Alas, the atmosphere didst please mine eyes,
But, alack, the food didst not suffice.
A bowl of pasta, dull and tasteless, came,
With two small meatballs, a paltry sum.
For fifteen dollars, I didst pay the price,
And left the place, still feeling quite nice.
Homeward, I went, with hunger pangs,
And there, a PB&J sandwich, I didst mangle."

"Malls are dead to me, but a gift card burned a hole in my pocket. We hit up a dusty department store, hoping for some classic retail therapy. The joint was tired, selection slim. Bummed me out, man. Felt like work, not fun."

"Upon mine eyes, this place didst seem most fair,
As featured on Man Vs Food, its fame didst declare.
With haste, we didst arrive, around the eleventh hour,
